parent_formation: V Corps (April-early May), IX Corps (May-June), British First Army

commander.name: Major-General John Ledlie Inglis Hawkesworth
commander.previous_service: Appointed GOC 4th Infantry Division March 1942, succeeding Major-General John Swayne. Led division from UK through Tunisia campaign (March-May 1943). Division landed in Algeria late March 1943, moved to Tunisia under V Corps (Lt-Gen Charles Allfrey), then transferred to IX Corps (Lt-Gen Brian Horrocks) for final offensive. KBE, CB, DSO & Bar. Died 3 June 1945.

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia: Arrived 23 March 1943 via Algeria. V Corps (Medjerda Valley sector, April). IX Corps (right flank, May operations). Post-campaign garrison duties North Africa (May-December 1943).

Churchill Mk III/IV Infantry Tank.organization: 21st Army Tank Brigade: 12th RTR, 48th RTR, 145th Regiment RAC. Organic to division since June 1942 conversion to 'mixed division' structure. Supported infantry in Operation Vulcan and Strike. 48th RTR alone lost 38 Churchill tanks during Tunisia fighting. Suffered additional losses at Cactus Farm engagement vs. Hermann Göring Division paratroopers.

tanks.note: Mixed division structure (June 1942-December 1943): two infantry brigades plus one tank brigade. 21st Army Tank Brigade replaced 11th Infantry Brigade in 1942 reorganization. Churchill tanks integrated into division tactical operations throughout Tunisia campaign. 48th RTR disabled German Tiger I tank (Tiger 131) during preliminary engagements before Battle of Longstop Hill - now the only operating Tiger tank in the world.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder.note: During Operation Strike night 5-6 May 1943, over 16,000 shells fired in two hours supporting 4th Division's advance alongside 4th Indian Division. Massive rolling barrage.

anti_aircraft.note: AA protection provided by attached First Army AA resources

supply_logistics.supply_status: GOOD - Division maintained adequate supply status throughout Tunisia operations. Arrived March 1943 fresh from UK with full equipment. Operations April-May 1943 supported by First Army logistics from Algiers and Bone ports (300-400km). Mixed division structure required coordination of infantry and tank brigade logistics. Heavy ammunition expenditure during Operation Strike bombardment. Combat losses required replacements during May-June.

Cactus Farm area: well-concealed defensive positions for German paratroopers. Valley approaches to Tunis.

composition: 2nd Battalion, Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry
subordinate_units.note: Active combat Tunisia campaign. Brigade never left 4th Division throughout the war. Participated in Operation Vulcan and Operation Strike. Suffered casualties as part of division-wide losses (over 300 in four battalions).

subordinate_units.commander: Brigadier Robert G.W. Callaghan (Dec 1941-April 1943), Brigadier Richard A. Hull (April-June 1943)
composition: 1st Battalion, Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment
subordinate_units.note: Moved to North Africa February 1943. Saw action at Battle of Oved Zara, Battle of Medjez Plain, Battle of Tunis. Active combat throughout Tunisia final offensive. Brigade remained with 4th Division except brief detachments.

Replaced 11th Infantry Brigade June 1942 in mixed division conversion. Organic to 4th Division throughout Tunisia. Arrived North Africa end March 1943. Helped break open approaches to Tunis in April. 48th RTR lost 38 Churchill tanks during fighting. 12th RTR engaged at Cactus Farm - 12 tanks destroyed by Hermann Göring Division paratroopers using Molotov cocktails and teller mines when advancing without infantry support. Tank brigade remained until December 1943 when replaced by 28th Infantry Brigade.

tactical_doctrine.role: British First Army mixed division (2 infantry brigades + 1 tank brigade) executing Tunisia campaign final offensive (Operations Vulcan and Strike, April-May 1943). Division fought under V Corps initially, then transferred to IX Corps for final offensive. Engaged elite German paratroopers (Hermann Göring Division) in costly fighting. Division fresh from UK, not desert-experienced like 8th Army formations. Specialized in combined infantry-tank operations using Churchill infantry tanks.

tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Not a true desert division - operated in northern Tunisia agricultural/hilly terrain. Arrived March 1943 from UK without desert experience. Learned combined infantry-tank tactics under fire. Mixed division structure provided immediate armor support unlike standard infantry divisions. Churchill tanks well-suited to infantry support but vulnerable without close infantry coordination (Cactus Farm lesson).

historical_context.formation_date: Pre-WWI Regular Army division, reformed 1939. Converted to mixed division June 1942.
historical_context.operational_status: Active - Heavy combat operations Q2 1943, then garrison duties post-campaign
major_battles: Arrival Tunisia (23 March 1943) - Division deployed from UK via Algeria, entered V Corps sector
Operation Vulcan preliminary attacks (22-28 April 1943) - V Corps offensive along Medjerda Valley toward Tunis. Division engaged German defenses, sustained casualties.
Transfer to IX Corps (early May 1943) - Redeployment for final offensive on right flank alongside 4th Indian Division

Cactus Farm engagement (early May 1943) - 12th RTR Churchill tanks assaulted by Hermann Göring Division paratroopers. 12 tanks destroyed by Molotov cocktails and teller mines. Infantry support coordination breakdown.

Operation Strike (5-13 May 1943) - Final offensive. Night 5-6 May: over 16,000 shells fired in two hours supporting division advance. British 4th Division (right) and 4th Indian Division (left) attacked under rolling barrage. Costly battles against German paratroopers.
Battle of Tunis (6-7 May 1943) - Division participated in drive to Tunis, British entry 7 May
Axis surrender Tunisia (13 May 1943) - 240,000 German and Italian troops captured, campaign ends
Post-campaign garrison duties (May-December 1943) - Division remained North Africa nine months, began reconversion to standard infantry division
